newsitem.title: UK: UK Takeover Panel not considering hostile rule change.
newsitem.headline: UK Takeover Panel not considering hostile rule change.

text.p: Britain's Takeover Panel has no plans to limit a bidder's ability to buy shares in a target company during a takeover, its director general Alistair Defriez said on Tuesday.
"I can assure you that there are no plans or proposals being considered that would change that rule," Defriez told Reuters.

He was responding to a Financial Times report on Tuesday which said the panel was reviewing its rules governing share purchases, including the bidder's right to buy up to 30 percent of a target's shares in the market before an offer gets regulatory clearance.
Defriez said he was "more than a bit surprised" by the article, which said the panel is being urged to change its rules to limit market purchases or stop the practice altogether.
The debate was prompted by last year's takeover of British regional electricity company Northern Electric by U.S. power group CalEnergy.

The paper said Northern's then chairman David Morris argued CalEnergy had an unfair advantage because it was able to buy 30 percent of Northern's shares at a time when the price was depressed because of the possibility of the offer being referred to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission (MMC).
When the bid was cleared Northern's share price recovered and CalEnergy's offer received 20 percent acceptances, in addition to its 30 percent, this meant the U.S. firm won by a tiny margin.

The Financial Times quoted Morris as saying the 30 percent limit should be cut to 15 percent. It said another option under consideration was for a target company to be able to appeal to the panel for the bidder's right to make share purchases if regulatory uncertainty was depressing its share price.
Defriez told Reuters that Morris was a great supporter of the panel and had expressed his views to the panel and to others.

But he said there was "no plan to change the rules in this area", although the panel was looking at other issues raised by Northern's battle with CalEnergy. "Its fair to say we are reviewing the issues raised (by the bid)," he added.
This was usual practice after a controversial bid and was simply part of the panel's ongoing aim of safeguarding shareholders' interests.
"It is quite normal and proper to examine what has happened," he added.

Corporate financiers have speculated that there could be changes to the rules regarding the buying of shares by advisors to the firms involved in a hostile bid, an issue raised by the Northern battle.

BZW, the investment banking arm of Britain's Barclays Plc, was last month criticised by the panel for failing to disclose all the facts, including a performance fee, during hearings over the conduct of the bid.

There was widespread debate about whether advisors to a company should be allowed to buy shares in a firm they were defending or making a bid for. Defriez said the review process into issues raised by the bids was continuing.

He said when it came to the question of a company buying shares in a bid target there were "arguments for and against" but the panel took the view "that the market should not be unduly fettered" and should be able to deal in the shares.
He said there was no intention to even review the limit on the buying of shares, adding that it would be a "draconian step" to further limit such buying.

And there were no plans to alter the Takeover Panel's "Blue Book", which lists its 10 guiding principles and its rules. The rules are "from time to time reviewed and revised to take account of changes in practice and opinion".
Defriez said it was important that the code should remain flexible and adaptable to changes in practice and sentiment. "One of the advantages of the code is its flexibility," he added.
